skin_conditions.name: Tinea Ringworm Candidiasis
causes: Superficial fungal infections caused by dermatophytes (Tinea) or yeast-like fungi (Candida species)
Flourish in warm, moist environments such as sweaty skin folds, tight clothing, and poor hygiene conditions
Can be contracted from direct skin contact, shared personal items, or contaminated surfaces
potential_harms: Persistent red, itchy, and scaly rashes that may resemble rings (in Tinea)
Skin breakdown leading to fissures, cracks, and increased risk of secondary bacterial infections
Can cause severe discomfort and affect daily activities if untreated
possible_progression: May spread to other areas of the skin, nails, or scalp
Chronic or recurrent infections may cause long-term skin discoloration, thickening, or scarring
Immunocompromised individuals are at risk for deeper or systemic fungal infections

skin_conditions.name: Vascular Lesion
causes: Congenital or acquired abnormalities in blood vessels (e.g., capillary malformations, hemangiomas)
May develop after trauma, aging, hormonal changes, or due to systemic vascular conditions
potential_harms: Usually asymptomatic but may cause significant cosmetic concerns
Some types (e.g., pyogenic granulomas) can bleed easily, ulcerate, or become painful
possible_progression: Most remain stable and harmless over time
Some may increase in size, become symptomatic, or require intervention for cosmetic or medical reasons

skin_conditions.name: Melanoma
causes: Malignant transformation of melanocytes due to cumulative DNA damage
Predominantly triggered by UV radiation (natural sunlight or tanning beds), especially in fair-skinned individuals
Risk factors include family history, numerous atypical moles, and a history of severe sunburns
potential_harms: Highly aggressive skin cancer capable of rapid local invasion and distant metastasis
Can affect lymph nodes, lungs, brain, and other organs if not caught early
Early signs may appear subtle and be easily overlooked
possible_progression: Early-stage melanoma is potentially curable with surgical excision
Advanced stages may require immunotherapy, targeted therapy, or chemotherapy, with variable prognosis
Delayed detection significantly reduces survival rates

skin_conditions.name: Squamous Cell Carcinoma
causes: Uncontrolled growth of squamous cells caused by DNA mutations, commonly due to chronic UV exposure
Increased risk with fair skin, immunosuppression, exposure to carcinogens, or previous radiation therapy
potential_harms: Capable of local tissue invasion, especially in high-risk areas like the lips, ears, or genitals
Can metastasize to lymph nodes or distant organs if neglected
May present as a persistent, non-healing ulcer, rough scaly patch, or raised lesion
possible_progression: Highly treatable in early stages with excision or other localized therapies
Advanced disease requires more aggressive treatment and may be life-threatening

skin_conditions.name: Dermatofibroma
causes: Benign fibrous skin nodule, often forming in response to minor trauma like insect bites or ingrown hairs
More common in adults and frequently seen on the lower legs
potential_harms: Typically harmless but may cause localized itching, tenderness, or aesthetic discomfort
Rarely mistaken for melanoma or other growths due to appearance
possible_progression: Generally stable and non-progressive
Can be surgically removed if symptomatic or cosmetically unwanted

skin_conditions.name: Melanocytic Nevus
causes: Clusters of pigment-producing melanocytes, often influenced by genetic predisposition and sun exposure
Can appear during childhood or develop later in life
potential_harms: Most moles are benign, but atypical or dysplastic nevi have a risk of malignant transformation
Changes in size, shape, border, or color may indicate melanoma
possible_progression: Stable moles typically do not require intervention
Regular monitoring is essential to detect early signs of melanoma development

skin_conditions.name: Atopic Dermatitis
causes: Chronic inflammatory skin disorder caused by genetic mutations affecting the skin barrier
Triggered by allergens, irritants (soaps, fabrics), environmental changes, stress, or infections
potential_harms: Intense itching, inflammation, and dryness can severely impact quality of life
Scratching can cause skin damage and increase risk of bacterial, viral, or fungal infections
possible_progression: Flares and remissions are typical; poorly managed cases may become chronic and lichenified
Often associated with asthma, hay fever, and food allergies

skin_conditions.name: Benign Keratosis
causes: Noncancerous epidermal growths commonly associated with aging
Exact cause unclear; likely involves genetic factors and cumulative sun exposure
potential_harms: Cosmetically concerning, especially when large, raised, or pigmented
Can become irritated, itchy, or inflamed if rubbed or scratched
possible_progression: Generally harmless and stable over time
May increase in number and size; lesions can be removed for cosmetic or comfort reasons

skin_conditions.name: Actinic Keratosis
causes: Premalignant lesions resulting from long-term ultraviolet exposure
Common in fair-skinned individuals and those with high lifetime sun exposure
potential_harms: Can progress to invasive squamous cell carcinoma if untreated
Lesions may be rough, scaly, and sensitive, particularly on sun-exposed areas
possible_progression: Early treatment (e.g., cryotherapy, topical agents, photodynamic therapy) reduces cancer risk
Regular monitoring is critical to identify malignant transformation early
